definitions.definition: To put a mark on (something); to make (something) recognizable by a mark; to label or write on (something).
definitions.example: to mark a box or bale of merchandise

definitions.definition: To leave a mark (often an undesirable or unwanted one) on (something).
definitions.example: See where this pencil has marked the paper.

definitions.definition: To have a long-lasting negative impact on (someone or something).
To create an indication of (a location).
definitions.example: She folded over the corner of the page to mark where she left off reading.

definitions.definition: To be an indication of (something); to show where (something) is located.
definitions.example: A bell marked the end of visiting hours.

definitions.definition: To indicate (something) in writing or by other symbols.
definitions.example: In her Bible, the words of Christ were marked in red.

definitions.definition: To create (a mark) on a surface.
To celebrate or acknowledge (an event) through an action of some kind.
definitions.example: The national holiday is marked by fireworks.

definitions.definition: (of things) To identify (someone as a particular type of person or as having a particular role).
definitions.example: His courage and energy marked him as a leader.

definitions.definition: (of people) To assign (someone) to a particular category or class.
(of people) To choose or intend (someone) for a particular end or purpose.
To be a point in time or space at which something takes place; to accompany or be accompanied by (an event, action, etc.); to coincide with.
definitions.example: That summer marked the beginning of her obsession with cycling.

definitions.definition: To be typical or characteristic of (something).
To distinguish (one person or thing from another).
To focus one's attention on (something or someone); to pay attention to, to take note of.
definitions.example: Mark my words: that boy’s up to no good.

definitions.definition: To become aware of (something) through the physical senses.
To hold (someone) in one's line of sight.
To indicate the correctness of and give a score to (a school assignment, exam answers, etc.).
definitions.example: The teacher had to spend her weekend marking all the tests.

definitions.definition: To record that (someone) has a particular status.
To keep account of; to enumerate and register; to keep score.
definitions.example: to mark the points in a game of billiards or a card game

definitions.definition: To follow a player not in possession of the ball when defending, to prevent them receiving a pass easily.
To catch the ball directly from a kick of 15 metres or more without having been touched in transit, resulting in a free kick.
To put a marker in the place of one's ball.
To sing softly, sometimes an octave lower than usual, in order to protect one's voice during a rehearsal.
The action of the verb to mark.
A mark.
The characteristic colouration and patterning of an animal.
Any configuration of a Petri net with a number of marks or tokens distributed across it.
